This kit aims to convert a "standard" prusa to a bowden set with minimal changes.
You need a standard 50mm extruder mount, and for instance a JHead hot-end, I will made more adapters on demand and with specs ;)

What's you need is ! 4x M2x15 (to secure the JHead)
2x M4x30 to mount the Extruder end and the support parts together.
2x M4x20 to secure the HotEnd (On your X-Carriage, or also on a Quick-Fit plate as on pictures) 4x M4 Nuts
6x M4 2x Pneufit for 6mm tubing (6mm out, 4mm in ideal for 3mm filament) And Approx 60cm of PTFE tubing.

print_settings.Notes:: Orient the clock so the numbers are on the print bed, then set the top layers = 0 to show pattern in back, and to save time and material.

description.text:
This is a simple wall clock I made to be displayed. It is 170mm in diameter and 23mm thick.

In order to save material and time, I oriented the clock to have the numbers facing down on the print bed, then set the top layers = 0 so that the infill shows on the back. You can mess around with the infill to find the right look for you. I used about 13% infill, grid design.

I also oriented the infill so that the grid design will hang the clock perfectly in the center when putting it onto a wall. This took away the need to put a hole into the design.

I bought the clock movement in a four pack for $15 from Hobby Lobby (see URL at bottom) but any crafts store should have a one that fits. The hole in the back for the movement is 56mm by 58mm.

https://www.hobbylobby.com/Crafts-Hobbies/Wood-Crafting/Clock-Making/Mini-Quartz-Clock-Movement-Value-Pack---1-4/p/29759

author: PeterMGrund

title: Prusa I3 MK2S Y-Axis guide/brace RJ4JP 0108

description.text:
Update: Be carefull with the screws not to crack the braces!
Slightly widening the holes could be neccessary!

A brace for the right side of the Y-Axis.
I noticed that I could wiggle my bed a little and made this thing which basically
is based on thing https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1848700 (Thank You for that!) but completly built from scratch.
For the right brace take one of those bearings and cut it in the middle and
use sanding paper or whatever to shorten both halves about 1mm.
(No room for complete ones due to shape of the frame)
It provides much better guidance then just one bearing.
Beware, espacially with new bearings you will have some friction at the start
and the printers self test most probably will fail.
Honestly, for that heavy duty high acceleration test to pass you really need a very loose bed.
No matter what, I take it, once you print those accessories your printer is already set up well and the self test not neccessary, anymore.
Put it in high power mode for the XYZ cal. and do some 1-3 prints (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1919441)
for the bearings and rods work themselves in.
Print orientation for the braces as in the picture.

Made with PETG from these guys https://www.3dpsp.de/ as all my other printer parts.
No drooping or degrading at all....
This stuff turned out to be quite fine to process.
It is quite sturdy, no problems with adhesion at all.
And really nice and brilliant colours for a reasonable price.

title: LED Matrix Stand and Raspberry Pi Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a stand for the Adafruit LED panels.
The one I bought is this one:
https://www.adafruit.com/product/2276
...and I used a Pi with this HAT:
https://www.adafruit.com/product/2345

There are a ton of HUB75-compatible displays out there and I'm not sure if the dimensions are all the same. But this build works with the above components.

Model consists of two parts: An arm that you use to prop up the display at a 20-degree angle, and a simple mount for your Raspberry Pi.

The arm is easy. Orient it the way it makes sense to avoid supports. The LED panel comes with M3 threaded inserts and that's what the holes are designed to mate with. You print the arm twice (once for each side). All you need are four screws and you're done.

The Raspberry pi mount is a little more involved. The LED panel came with a really short HUB75 connector so you really can't mount the Pi towards the center where there are already inserts. What I ended up doing is adding an M3 heatset insert to the back of the panel near where you plug the cable in (http://amzn.to/2BWi75K if you don't already have these). The panel already has the holes they just aren't stuffed. Again soldering iron method works well but be careful 'cause you only have one shot at it.

The mount I created consists of a tongue you can use to hang off of the hole mentioned above (note the photo has an older version of the mount - the one in this project has a slightly longer tongue so you can add/remove it with the pi attached). The mount is designed to take 2.5mm heat set inserts (the ones I used had a max outer diameter of 4.04mm with an overall length of 5.56mm). The soldering iron method works well, but I also used a thin metal spatula to drive it the last couple of millimeters to get a nice flush finish. I have an assortment box full of inserts, but if you don't have that here's what you need:
http://amzn.to/2DezUBy

Sounds harder than it is. It's actually pretty easy if you've used heat set inserts before.

UPDATE: I just looked on the Adafruit site and noticed the panel they have pictured is slightly different than mine. The one I have came with the inserts already installed at the midpoint on either side. In their picture they are missing. Shouldn't be a big deal but you might need a couple of more M3 inserts.

title: LEGO attachable Raspberry Pi Zero W case

description.text:
When looking for a Raspberry Pi W Zero case that could be attached to LEGO bricks and plates, I did not find one that quite fit my needs.

I decided to merge two good existing models. Using geertvda's Raspberry Pi W Zero case which is one of my favorite cases, and bengineering's Classic LEGO brick model which I consider one of the best LEGO brick models, I was able to make a nice case that attached to LEGO bricks or a LEGO plate.

The case is made by printing the modified case bottom in this thing, and printing the case top file in gertvda's thing 2171313 (file: pi_zero_w_case_v3_top_gpio_cooling_fin.stl).
Raspberry Pi Zero W case by gertvda files

The new case bottom snaps on to "real" LEGO bricks with a nice click and feels securely attached. I printed the case in both PLA and ABS. I preferred the cases made in ABS.

Check out the LEGO plate thing: 2741302 that can be used to attach this case to non-LEGO projects.

description.text:
I wanted a replacement for the kit spool holder provided with my Anet A8. I found many different versions but I only had one skateboard bearing and I couldn't be bothered to wait for my new ones to arrive! So I decided to design a horizontal spool holder that not only uses 1 bearing but as an added plus is compatible with all sizes of Spool.

This is my first design so ANY feedback is welcome. If its something I can fix, I will! Cheers!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This is my very first published make. Enjoy!

Materials Needed:
1 x Filament Spool Holder
2 x Spool Hub - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1045196 (Credit to JP1)
2 x M8 Nuts
1 x 608RS Skateboard bearing
1 x 8mm threaded rod (approx. 15cm long)

Instructions:
1) Insert skateboard bearing into filament spool holder
2)Thread the rod with 1 of the M8 nuts (about 3.5 cm into the rod)
3) place the spool hub followed by the filament spool of your choice and then another spool hub
4) then add the remaining nut until it comes in contact with the spool hub.

See the pics above for clarification :)

P.S - I found that adding a non-slip mat underneath this holder keeps it in place when the spool gets a little low and becomes lighter.

title: Surface Pro - Recharging Station
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a charging station for the Microsoft Surface, Surface Pro 3 or any computer that is thinner than 25mm. My Surface devices are all encased in the UAG Urban Armor gear so - extra thick.

It has 3 slots so you can use it to hold 3 devices at any given time. I have 3 Surface devices and I hate laying them ontop of one another to charge. The holes are designed so the charging wires can run through the bottom through the hole to the devices to charge. The holes are also going to try and stop the wires from falling through all the time. I may add more holes if needed.

This thing is huge and takes up 95% of the build area of my Makerbot Replicator 5th gen. Printing at 10% infill at .2mm will take about 18 hours! So, this is a long print. I am printing in draft mode and it will take 6hrs.

Also, glue 2mm foam to the bottom so it slides around less.

title: OpenPilotCC to KK Adaptor Plate and housing

description.text:
An adaptor plate/housing to mount an openpilot Copter Control board on a copter frame designed for a KKMulticopter board.
A lot of the cheap frames you get from places like Hobby King and Ebay are designed to mount one of the cheap KK Multicopter control boards. This adapter gives both a protective housing for the Open Pilot Copter Control board, and a KK form factor.
This is still a work in progress. I'm working with SketchUp, which whilst being very easy to use for a beginner like myself, doesn't have some of the features I need to complete this, so I will have to learn something else.
I will be doing a lid for this, along with another mounting plate for the accessories such as GPS and bluetooth, and the RC receiver.
Current issues: The mounting screws for the CC board are slightly off, and I can't find an easy way in SketchUp to ammend them.
Print out the STL, and the CC board should sit nicely in it. Due to ill fitting holes, use self tapping screws for now to secure the board.

description.text:
Meet the perfect base for mini fpv racing gates! Works great for indoor flying and, with the help of a few stones, can put up a good fight against wind! The geometry is optimized for standard FDM printers meaning that bases can be printed fast, using little plastic while maintaining structural integrity. After just a few hours of printing, I had enough bases to have a blast racing my tiny whoop around the house!

The diameter of the central hole is set to fit the carbon rods of the Premier RC race gates, however if you would like to make this part for a slightly different sized rod, I would be happy to try to get an updated file to you!

I have also included a lid file for use with sand or other heavy substance. If anyone does try this, please let me know how it went.

Happy whooping!

description.text:
I designed this Nerf Phoenix LTX battery cover to replace one that was missing on a used tagger I purchased. This battery cover should fit just as well as the original cover. It requires two M3 8mm screws to hold it to the Phoenix. The lower part of the screw hole is intentionally a little snug so when the screws are backed out, they can stay in the cover without falling out.

I printed this battery cover on its side with PLA and using an adhesion plate. The top side of the cover comes out near perfect while the bottom side needs some clean up because of the supports to look good. Once it is printed, make sure all the small support pieces are cleared off where it touches the gun. If not, it may not slip on like it is suppose to, but it will indeed fit when they are clean. If you print this and it works for you, please let me know in the comments.

I uploaded the "v2" which has the ridges around the outer rim to make it look more like the original.

M3 8mm Screws from Amazon: http://amzn.to/2lhafR7
M3 8mm Screws: https://www.banggood.com/Suleve-M3ASH1-10pcs-M3-Hex-Socket-Cap-Head-Screws-Alloy-Steel-Titanium-Plated-12_9-Grade-p-1216271.html?p=6Z050013977120130325

If you find this useful, consider sending me a dollar or two. I'd sure appreciate it.

This is a neat little box you can use to store a CPU in. This should fit most AMD CPUs, but it will definitely fit 754, 939, AM2, AM2+, AM3, and AM3+. It might fit FM1, FM2, FM2+, or AM1, but I haven't tried it out. It may also hold other CPUs of the same size.

You may have to rotate this in your printing software. I had to in XYXware Pro, but it shouldn't be hard to do.

I test printed this using a blue PLA, on an XYZPrinting Da Vinci Jr. 1.0 Pro at 200c, with no supports, no rafts, and 10% infill. Should work fine using any plastic or infill type, but I recommend 10%.

The holder is in two parts, each a different STL file, and I recommend printing separately. The bottom piece is 10mm high, and the top is 12.5mm high. The inside is 10mm tall. The box is 48x48mm large, and the inside is 42x42. Filing may be needed on some of the inside parts depending on the quality of your 3D printer. I just had to file down a bit of sprew-like pieces that shouldn't be there.

The box should fit together snugly, and look decently flush around the outside. You may want to stick a small piece of soft anti-static foam, but this should not be needed, so long as you do not excessively shake the box with a CPU inside.

Was tested using a 754 Athlon64 3200+, and designed off the AM3 size specifications from AMD.

Designed using Autodesk's Fusion 360.

description.text:
This is my snowflake for the #BlocksCADSnowflake contest. I took things a different direction and used the Torus shape, offset on the X access and then rotated using the loop command to create the shape. It's right at 100mm in width and prints well. The torus has 6 faces to ensure the bottom of the snowflake is flat and printer friendly.

I also set the number of sides as a variable so you can easily change the shape of the snowflake. Just change that variable and render to see what is possible.

You can hang the snowflake using one fo the edge holes, or print a bunch of them to use as coasters around the house.

The BlocksCAD project page is here: https://www.blockscad3d.com/community/projects/68209

Enjoy!

Printer:

FLSUN Kossel Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

4mm Nozzle

Infill:

10% (but really doesn't matter)

Notes:

Be sure to lay your first layer down slow to ensure good bed adhesion with the fine line work. I ran my first 2 layers at 10mm/second. Should be an simple print.

Updated. Will post as a remix too...
Update - handle no longer requires supports to print. Has "Screwdriver-o-matic" on the side

  • body has an internal spring. I did this in pla but seems to hold well so far. Print real slow with a low layer height (I used 0.12). You may get strings where the spring is to the body, but they help to stabilise the spring when the nozzle is above it printing the next layer. A lucky side effect of stringing!
    Files are Screwdriver-o-matic 5&6.

Updating again soon. With printed integral spring. if anyone's bothered! Printing it real slow...

Final version is v7. Print the body upright with no supports.
Print the handle with supports to buildplate.
Find a suitable spring (I used 9mm x 80mm).
Insert a hex bit.
Press the 2 'F's to screw in, 2 'R's to screw out.
About 7hrs print time at 0.2 height.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Lv5TUKp7SvY&feature=youtu.be

(This is very much in its infancy.
Attempting to make a fully functional Yankee Screwdriver... Any remixes / help is appreciated.
Using Tinkercad.

EDIT...Still waiting for new nozzles so cant print yet. Designed with a 0.2 nozzle in mind. Uploaded v2. My aim is to have only 1 handle for both forward and reverse.

EDIT...Another one of many updates. Thinner guides in handle. 2 guides instead of 6. 8mm deep hex hole.

EDIT... V5 is now being printed. Requires a loose 80mm x 9mm spring. Fully functional reversible Yankee Screwdriver. Fingers crossed!)

title: Bowden Head Tube Guide Anet A8 Style

description.text: This thing guides the tube of your bowden extruder so that it bends less or not at all at the push fitting on the extruder. I made this after the fitting on mine broke and it pushed the tube out instead of extruding. Ruined a 10 hour print but since I put this on there's been no hints of an issue. It's easy to install between the screws on most Anet A8 heads. I have included the SolidWorks 2016 file it's made from. There's a screen shot showing how to set the distance. I measured from the front of the bowden mount surface to the back of the tube to get the distance then add 2.25mm to it to center the 4.5mm tube hole. Don't worry it makes sense in my head.

remixed_from.title: Flying Tourbillon Model V (Daniels Double Independant Wheel Remontoir Escapement)

description.text:
I modified a few parts from the original design and added one new one:

  • split Frame b into two pieces held together with a 2.5mm screw. This makes it easier to print. I also a hex hole a little smaller so that it fits more tightly (T5a, T5b). T5b needs to be turned the other way up before you print it.
  • reduced the diameter of the roller so that the pallet does not collide with it (T5d).
  • adapted a sprocket from one of the other Tourbillon models, and added a hole for a grub screw (holy sprocket hex).

I've included a blender file which might help to understand how the pieces fit together.

description.text:
I had an old gimbal that I wanted to put to use. I also wanted to see if my object was in the frame, so I added an old phone car mount, and it works great. This gimbal was designed for a hero4, so I printed a hero5 camera mount and used two 3m bolts and nuts to attach it to the gimbal's camera plate. This allowed me to adjust the roll and pitch of the gimbal. You will have to use something to balance the yaw. I used an old wheel weight from a car. To control the gimbal I used a joystick and configured it through the storm32 GUI. Works perfect, If you get the joystick listed below you can control pan, tilt, one button press for re-centering and two/three button press to select pan mode(PAN, PAN, PAN/PAN, HOLD, PAN) wiring diagrams will be attached. To power the gimbal I used three 18650 batteries in series, which provides enough power to get the job done. You can use any battery configuration that you see fit. Only use 2s to 4s. Change the design as you need to. I remixed this using Tinkercad.

Gimbal: www.goodluckbuy.com/3-axis-brushless-gimbal-camera-mount-with-32bit-storm32-controller-for-gopro-3-4-fpv-black.html

Phone mount: http://www.ebay.com/itm/like/302479122452

joystick: http://www.goodluckbuy.com/storm32-bgc-32bit-3-axis-brushless-gimbal-controller-v1-31-drv8313-with-2-sensors-and-joystick-.html ----- This joystick is a controller and IMU bundle. You can have enough controllers and IMUs but if you want just the joystick it can probably found on amazon or ebay for a cheaper price.

Test Footage. it is edited but no stabilization was added. I just wanted to film my kids on Christmas day riding in my son's new whip
https://youtu.be/0HxtDP18uuw

setting up storm32 gimbal controller: Part 1- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HwaHjRw1Qqg

description.text:
The mini blinds in the garage when we moved into the house had a rod, but the part that hooks to the hook to open and close the blinds was gone. This cap solved that problem. The hole in the bottom of the cap is 11mm diameter. the rod comes in at 11.5mm. it worked out to be a nice tight fit.. although probably could have pushed the hole out to 11.5 so the rod will go all the way in. I was worried that the pla would snap, so it is bulky on purpose.

Since I assume there will be other diameter rods out there, I have included the fusion 360 export. you can import it back into fusion 360 and by selecting the right item on the timeline, can modify the hole size or the cylinder diameter.. etc.

ok did a little bit more tweaking- the original BlindRodCap.stl goes with the v6 fusion 360 file. The v8 version of the stl and fusion file has the big hole in the cap .5mm larger, the hole that attaches to the blind is chamfered, and I cleaned up the little bulge that stuck out on either side of the transition between the main cap and the part that attaches to the blind.

while I was at it I found that the distance between flats for the standard size hex wand was 5/16. From that I was able to use fusion 360 to modify the design to make a hex version.

remixed_from.title: Sine Thread, fast printable thread library.

description.text:
We all know the story. You're down to your last pool cue, it's Christmas day, and thunk the last tip breaks off. What to do?? PRINT THE THINGS!

Thanks to mingofmongo I've grafted a cue tip to the end of a threaded section. I've kept the tip separate from the thread so you can tweak them independently to suit your cue and preference.

There is so much potential for tweaking here. I've tried a tip with lots of curve, and a flatter curve. The flatter the tip the easier it is to use.

Printed with 0.1mm layers, and 30% infill. Increase the infill if you want a harsher more solid feel to the cue.

Enjoy!!

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fnRmhDbGood

this is my own design for a chimera with volcano hotends for the airwolf printer
there is an included back plate that you can use to attach something to as I did in the picture
You can print this without supports, the parts cooling fan is a standard 30mm fan
with this design you do NOT need to print any other parts, extend the legs/arms to trip the end stops it is 100% interchangeable with the airwolf hotend . I used the 4mm adjustment screw from my stock hotend on this unit but you can just get a 4mm screw and nut that is at least 20mm long to use if you dont want to take it from the stock unit. Once you use this you will never go back, I promise.
there is a hole next to the parts cooling fan I used the stock ptfe tubing put it thru the whole then placed a washer over a 4mm bolt and threaded it into the stock tubing this give me something to run the wires to the back of the printer without putting extra weight on the 1.75mm ptfe tubing. You can do it however you want of course

As always I accept tips

comments.text: Do you have to make any changes to the firmware for this hotend upgrade?
comments.author: danthony2017

comments.text:
you will have to change the steps per mm but you can do that via gcode command if you wanted to
you have to use new extruders because its 1.75mm filament as most people will want to use titan extruders these days
you would have to change the extruder steps per/mm to match what the titan will be doing
a good estep for the titan seems to be between 460 and 479
the gcode command to change the steps/mm would be
M92 E479:479
that would set both extruders to 479 for using titan extruders

title: UNC Ram Logo - Four Color Print

description.text:
I was thinking of printing all the parts separate and gluing it together somehow but that seemed like way too much work. Instead I cut the frame apart from the background inserts and then rescaled each background with the same color to the same height 0.5 mm from each other. This way its possible to start the printer with one color and then switch out the second color though out the print. On this one the white background was lowest, then grey and then light blue.

Download all the parts, when arranging all the pieces in your slicer, unlock scaling and reset the insert pieces together half a milometer or so apart from each other on the z axis. Then tell your printer to stop at that height to switch filament.

remixed_from.author: DrGeeky
remixed_from.title: Silica Desiccant Case / Humidifier for Humidor

description.text:
This is an active/passive humidifier for a humidor. you can add a 30mm fan to it to make it work for larger humidors and provide circulation. I am building this as an intermediate step to a fully automated humidor.

Instructions:

  1. print box.
  2. obtain WET floral foam. needs to be the wet kind. http://a.co/b50odSu
  3. put in the box.
  4. close the box.
  5. buy Propylene Glycol. http://a.co/eQmdijI
  6. mix Propylene Glycol 50% with distilled water.
  7. drip into box until saturated but not dripping.
  8. add 30mm fan (optional)

title: LED Light Strip Holder for Original Prusa I3

description.text:
These are a pair of sturdy arms for holding a touch sensitive LED light strip above the Prusa I3 printer. The light strip ends up approximately 8 inches from the Z plate and 10 inches off of the print bed. It does a great job of illuminating the printer.

As far as I know, my design will work with any of the Original Prusa I3 printers with the metal Z plate. I am making the assumption that the Z plate thickness and the height of the rail with 'PRUSA' written on it have not changed. If either of those dimensions are different on your printer, let me know and I'll adapt my models.

The light I used was purchased from Fry's Electronics:
https://www.frys.com/product/9400631

My arms will only work if the light you have has the same body shape.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.020

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Pretty basic print with black PLA. No supports or rafts. In Slic3r (Prusa Edition) I just selected the '.020 mm NORMAL' setting.

Step 1 - Identify the arms

I designed the arms asymmetrically. The reason for this is that the Prusa Z plate is chamfered on the internal corners. I had to chamfer the arms to clear these features so I ended up with a left arm and a right arm.

You can easily identify the arms by looking for the power cord channel on the outside of one of the arms. Only the left arm has the channel in it.

The left arm (bottom of the image) has a channel for the power cord. The right arm does not. Step 2 - Insert the power cord into the channel

I didn't want to have to zip tie the cord to one of the arms so I included a little channel for the power cord to slip into.

Push the cord into the channel. The cord could be a little tight going in depending on how your print turns out compared to mine. However, once the wire is all the way in, it should be loose in the channel.

It isn't too hard to adjust the length of the cord hanging from the end of the arm but I would recommend you leave a few inches hanging out at this time to make it easier to connect to the light later.

Slip the power cord into the channel. Leave a couple of inches hanging out of the end. Continue slipping the cord in until you get to the rear portion of the arm. Step 3 - Install the arms

The arms should loop around the back of the Z plate. Loop the lower C-channel under the plate about .25 inch away from the chamfer on the Z plate. If you try to install the arm with it in line with the chamfer on the Z plate, you won't be able to get it on.

Pull the arm up to get the arm seated against the under side of the Z plate. You might have to wiggle the arm a bit side to side (NOT front to back!) to get it fully seated.

Once the arm is fully seated, push from the back of the arm to pop it onto the Z plate. The upper piece of the arm will click over the plate and hold the arm from rotating backwards.

Finally, slide the arm all the way out against the edge of the Z plate. The arm will fit over and hide the chamfer.

Repeat the process for the other arm.

Put the arm behind the Z plate and loop the hook under the plate. Be sure to install the arm at least 0.25 inches from the edge to avoid the chamfer. Push the back of the arm to get the upper clip to pop over the Z plate. Once installed, slide the arm against the side of the Z plate. Install the other arm the same way. Step 4 - Identify the ends of the light bar

The light bar that you must use: https://www.frys.com/product/9400631

The light bar has two modes: always on or touch sensitive. The touch sensitive mode has 3 brightness levels (4 if you include 'off' as a brightness).

To enable always on, you'll need to plug the power into the end of the light bar without the circuits. Using this end, the light will only turn off if you unplug it.

To enable touch sensitive mode, plug the power into the end with the circuits. The light will come on and cycle through the brightness levels as you touch the metal case.

The 24 LED 12 inch light bar: https://www.frys.com/product/9400631 If you plug the cord into the end with the circuits, the light will be in touch sensitive mode. Step 5 - Install the light bar

The light bar will slide into the clips on the ends of the arms. They are a tight fit because I didn't want the light moving around after being installed. Also, a tight fit makes the arms more stable.

Slight the right end of the light bar into the right arm. Slide it until about 3/4 of an inch (19mm) of the light bar is hanging out to the right of the arm clip.

Repeat for the left side, again pushing 3/4 inch past the clip.

Slide the light bar into the right arm as shown. Then slide it into the left arm. Step 5 - Connecting the power cord

Push the connector into the left side of the light bar. Hopefully you remembered to put the correct side on the end to choose the mode you wanted.

Push the excess power cord into the channel and pull the slack from the back of the print.

Plug the power cord into your wall and enjoy a well lit print surface.

Plug in the power cord. Push the excess through the arm. Turn on the light and enjoy illuminated printing. Dark room with only the LED light on. I am very pleased with how bright it is.

1. Christmas gift for my first printer

I received the LED light strip as a gift for Christmas. I had just finished assembling my first 3D printer a week before Christmas so the light was a great gift.

However, the light strip came with simple mounts for mounting the strip to the wall or roof of a cabinet. This was not very useful with my printer.

I decided that I needed to design and print light holders.

2. Version 1 Design

Christmas morning I designed the first iteration of the arms with these basic goals:

  • It needed to reach as far forward on the printer as possible (the length of the arms were limited by how big of an item I can print on the bed)
  • It needed to clear the print head and filament even when the head maxed out its travel
  • It had to be sturdy
  • It should look like it belongs on the printer

Following these basic guidelines, I quickly drew the model and printed out my first set of arms.

The first arms were done in Prusa Silver because that is what I had loaded at the time. 3. Version 1 Results

The first arms worked... mostly.

I originally decided to use the little clips that came with the LED light strip. They attached to the ends of my arms with a single screw. Being new to printing, I didn't know what size to make the hole on the end of the arm. I made the hole 0.100 inch for a screw that was 0.145 inch on the outside of the threads.

As I screwed them in, I knew they were too tight and before they even started to hold the clips in place, the PLA cracked.

Also, the arms ended up being too flexible and loose around the Z plate.

Finally, the last thing I didn't like was the lack of cord management.

The first arms kind of worked but they needed to be better. 4. Version 2 Design

The first change I made was to enlarge the screw holes from 0.100 to 0.120 inch so that the screws could more easily thread into the arms.

I also changed the shape of the Z plate channel to tighten it up a bit so the arms couldn't flop around.

I changed the rear of the arm to put more material where it counts. I thickened up the back edge to prevent the arms from flexing as much.

Finally, I added a channel for the cord to fit into. I didn't want to use zip ties to hold it so I made the channel oversized and added a thin wall to hold the cord inside. I also added 4 small tabs to make it hard for the cord to come out once it was installed.

Version 2 was printed in black to better match my printer 5. Version 2 Results

The arms fit the Z plate much better and the redesign made the arms much sturdier. However, I still didn't go large enough on the screw holes. The screws went in further, but they did end up cracking the plastic anyway.

The cord slot worked well but my design was a little too tight and made the cord hard to install.

Version 2 worked much better but I still wasn't happy. 6. Integrate clamp design

At this point in time I considered tossing the stock light clamps and printing my own. I'm not very familiar with the tolerances of 3D printing since I've never owned one so I questioned whether I could make a good enough clamp to hold the light fixture.

The clamp is a little complicated because it fits the extrusion of the light fixture. I modeled it up the best I could by measuring it with calipers.

I decided to print a sample to test fit the clamp. The sample was a little tight on the light fixture but worked way better than I expected.

The clamp test worked out well and I didn't have to spend a bunch of time printing out the whole arm to test. 7. Version 3 Design

The biggest change in Version 3 was the addition of the built-in clamps. Other changes were minor like tweaking the Z plate clamp to be just a little tighter and opening up the power cord channel a bit to make installation easier.

I also added my user name (BUILD 42) to both arms.

I then printed the final parts in black.

Version 3, the final product. 8. Version 3 Results

Honestly, there isn't really anything I can think of that I would change at this point. The arms fit the Z plate very well, the light strip slides in relatively easily and is held firmly and the cord channel is easy to work with and holds the cord in place.

Version 3 installed Version 3 clearance with head maxed up and left. The filament just barely touches the arm. Version 3 clearance with head maxed up and right. No interference on this side.

author: bushka

description.text:
This is a case for the uBITX transceiver, a general coverage ham radio transceiver designed by VU2ESE.

This case is meant to be printed in three parts and assembled using the included hardware with the uBITX. It is designed to print on smaller volume printers such as the MakerBot or the FlashForge Creator. This also provides the opportunity to print in multiple colors for a more attractive case.

The custom knobs are also available for purchase on Shapeways:
Encoder knob
Volume knob

Revisions (v1.0):

  • Adjusted location of volume knob
  • Internally recessed audio/key jacks to allow the nut to get more 'bite' into the jack
  • Filleted corners of front/back to make printing a bit easier and sharpen up the appearance
  • Signature moved to back left of chassis where it is mostly out of sight
  • Front/back modified to be more robust - previous version was particularly vulnerable to breaking at the base of the snap tabs. Time will tell on this one!

v1.01

  • Added custom-printed knobs!

v1.02

  • Added a pen cap microphone case - now all parts for full assembly are included. The microphone fits neatly as a replacement pen cap to a uni-ball micro-point pen.

Some tips:

  • I printed in PETG - Other materials should be possible, but the snap-together case may not work as well with more rigid or less robust plastics.
  • Before case assembly, file the ridges on the face/back tabs to smooth them out just a bit and remove any printing irregularities
  • Print the front/back with a WIDE brim (I go 10 wide, 2 high) - that will help prevent warping. These parts are a bit of a worst case scenario for warping. The body does not require this and is very easy to print
  • If you don't like (or break off) the snap tabs, it should be no problem to drill a hole somewhere where the parts overlap and secure with self-tapping screws

Assembly:

  • Wire up uBITX and attach all front/back parts
  • I used 1" copper tape on the front audio jacks to provide a common ground between them (pictured). A more extensive lining of copper tape could easily be used, if desired
  • Slide main board into grooves on face part
  • Plug in the audio/digital jacks onto the uBITX board
  • You will need to bend U3 to get it out of the way a bit
  • Slide the "main" part onto the uBITX main board from the rear, and then, one side at a time, push the side tab inward while applying a bit of force to the "main" part and allow it to move forward and snap into place. Repeat for the other tab.
  • Plug in rear connections
  • Slide "back" part into place and snap it in the same way you did the front face
  • Knobs are just friction-fit - the volume knob will need to be cut down to fit the included knob
  • Microphone element goes in the 'Body' part, and the switch goes in the rectangular hole on the 'Switch' part, with leads bent 90 degrees downwards (it's a tight fit). There is a divider to keep the leads from shorting out. Pass the wires from the microphone and switch down through the hole in the side, or alternatively through the bottom, if you prefer. I wired a 3.5mm TRS jack very close to the microphone, and use a 3.5mm M-M shielded cable to connect to the uBITX
  • Connect up, and make QSOs!

title: Tusk cooling for Duet smart effector

description.text:
The Duet Smart Effector is a nice upgrade to a plastic effector. Nozzle-based probing, guaranteed-precise dimensions, built-in lights, and easy-to-detach cables. However, the provided 40mm fan shroud didn't seem to generate enough cooling with the 40mm fan I had, and axial fans aren't known to be great for part cooling anyway.

I saw the Tusk fan shroud blog and wanted to try the concept with this 40mm x 20mm blower fan.

This design tries carefully to:

  • minimize any loss to printable area incurred when fan parts stick outside of the effector triangle: these parts stick out just a few mm and probably can't get any smaller without either changing the E3D fan duct or using a different blower fan
  • maximize the clearance from the bottom: for better visibility, as well as clearance from bed-mounting screws, there is about 2mm of clearance now
  • use a minimum of material: the fan body is used in a structural way

Parts Needed

  • 3x M3x20mm BHCS
  • 4mm Al tubing for tusks

Instructions:

  • print one of each part
    • go slow with the tusk shroud, as it needs good cooling; also, flip it so the bottom side is on the build plate (should have no overhangs)
    • same for the fan mount
  • print the tusk drill jig from here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2445660
  • create your tusks; I crimped mine with a PCB vise and used a hacksaw and sandpaper
  • enlarge the holes in the tusk mount to exactly 4mm, so that the tusks stay in place but can be rotated
  • form the screw threads for the tusk clip retaining screw, then attach these two together
  • attach fan to mount
  • remove effector screws and add the mount; the holes are placed to where the edge of the fan acts like a nut trap
  • tune part cooling settings

For extra clearance, I used smaller-head button-head cap screws (BHCS) instead of socket-head cap screws (SHCS) for the fan mount and the tusk mount.

In practice, the blower fan is not the quietest (although it is quieter than a typical 30mm hotend fan) and does not push the most air, but it does seems to work well enough in practice. If starting from scratch, I would seek out a smaller 40mm or quieter 30mm blower fan to eliminate the few mm of lost printable circle, plus also to maybe get some more airflow.

NOTE: The pictures show a mix of tusks with different hole sizes, and both extend a bit longer than necessary. I've since re-made these to be shorter and have a consistent 1/16" hole size.

Effector Fan Mount
Tusk Duct Bottom

Kossel 25K

description.text:
These models were designed in order to allow users to test their first layer adhesion and quality. The model is 0.3mm tall so it should use much plastic, while allowing you to see if your bed is properly leveled or if your leveling sensor is working properly. The model has a 20mm gap between the edge of your bed and the edge of the model in order to avoid clamps and other objects close to the edge.

I have uploaded some models that you can print depending on the size of your bed, but if the size of your bed is not in the list, leave a comment and I will generate a model for you. If I am not around to do it, you can always do it yourself by changing the Bed_X and Bed_Y variables of any of these models and then exporting it:

print_settings.Notes:: Don't try to print the last file, it is just there for viewing.

description.text:
Alright, well don't get your hopes up. Without dampers, better bearings, stiffer chassis and the ability to make fine adjustments a selfie stick still works better. However this does demonstrate the general principle.

It is designed to use 624ZZ bearings like these: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B071CFN91S
M4 nuts/bolts like these: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B017N7ZI72
Springs like these: https://www.homedepot.com/p/Everbilt-Spring-Assortment-Kit-84-Pack-13554/203133714

1/3/18 - See update below

However you can get the general idea using the printed bearing and pin with a few rubber bands.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

I used 0.2 with a 0.3mm nozzle

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Lay the struts, gimbal and platform pieces down flat so the "grain" goes the right way for strength.

Don't try to print the last file, it is just there for viewing.

Assembly:

Press in the bearings and screw the parts together. The Mount piece has a slot to insert a nut.
There are several pegs to use for the springs, pick a set of springs and pegs that work with the weight of your camera.

The mount was made for my G16 which is a larger point and shoot camera. You will probably have to shim the camera up until it just rights itself.

Warning! Use a wrist strap attached to the camera or photograph over a pillow.

Update 1/3/18

Published some Version 2 parts:

Modified the camera roll axis to use two bearings.
Changed all bearing mounts to snap in, rather than float.
Added holes and slots so additional M4 hardware can be hung on to fine tune the weight distribution.
Added a pistol grip
Lengthened the struts

This makes it almost useful. Balance it carefully so the camera just rights itself and floats in the middle of the travel and put some silicone on the joints. I can run around the yard and for the most part what jiggle gets through the camera's stabilization can handle.

print_settings.Notes:: Make sure to print two eyes.

description.text:
It is a puzzle box-esque penguin that I made for my sister, with just a couple of moves to unlock everything. Designed not to fall apart if it is anything but straight upside down.

If you're making this for someone else, posts can get lost, feet can break if the penguin is dropped from a height. (Make extras!)

You will need to glue the eyes in.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.5mm nozzle

Notes:

Make sure to print two eyes.

Cleaning up support

The beak will have very little support, but you'll need to remove it so that things fit. The BodyBack stl had some tough support to pull off. If you extrude too much on the first layer, you may need to sand edges (primarily the top edges of the wing as they slide into BodyBack).

Blender, and lots of iterations

Fitting and refitting to have accurate tolerances.

Overall design process:

  1. Outside shell
  2. Interior puzzle
  3. Cut outside shell vertexes free from the rest of the shell.
  4. Merge outside shell vertexes to interior puzzle parts.

Lessons learned:
"Locking post" tolerances are usually about 80-90% of the hole diameter.
The head popped free of the original one tab+post combination, requiring the back of HeadFace to be higher for the post, and adding another tab.
I am not an artist.

description.text:
This is a solder fume extractor. This is an improvement over the version I've made a few years ago that can be found at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:724350 . Only the base (stand) is changed. I lowered it and made the base larger to improve its stability.

This fume extractor uses carbon filters of 130mm x 130mm x 10mm. These are used for the HAKKO 491/493 fume extractor. To build it, you'll need:

  • 2 x carbon filters of 130mm x 130mm x 10mm.
  • 1 x 120 mm 12V computer fan
  • 1 x KCD1-101 switch
  • 1 x DC barrel power jack like the PRT-00119 from Sparkfun
  • 4 x 6-32 screws of 1.5" in length (38 mm)
  • 4 x 6-32 nuts
  • Some electrical wires

You also need a 12V power adapter with a 5.5 x 2.1 mm plug to power it.

You should not need support material to print it.

description.text:
This is a Bondtech QR mount for the Pegasus 12". It was designed for usage with an E3D Volcano and Bltouch bed leveling sensor. The design needs modified for it to work with an E3Dv6 and Bltouch sensor. The top portion is the standard bondtech QR top mount piece. The following hardware is needed. You will have plenty of extra heat set inserts and screws since the minimum package quantities are 50 to 100.

-2 x MCMASTER 93365A156 10-32 x 375 Heat set insert for mounting top portion of bondtech extruder mount
-2 x MCMASTER 93365A120 4-40 x135 Heat set insert for mounting bltouch sensor
-2 x Mcmaster 91251A342 10-32 Socket head screws for mounting top portion of bondtech extruder mount.

I have attached the source Solidworks files which can be modified and a step file of the mount.

edit: I uploaded the firmware I am currently running. It works well with the Bltouch. You may need to add a thin shim under the Bltouch if your print height is a little short.

I was tired of my sockets ending up out of order and rolling about in my tool box. So I made this set of metric and standard (SAE, inch) holders that can be secured to your tool box with glue or assembled with a flexible magnet strip (available at walmart 1" wide x 10 foot for about $4USD). The magnet method is what I did. It lightly holds the sockets from falling out and secures it to the bottom of a metal tool box.

Designed in Inventor based on standard sockets from Craftsman.

I tested several brands of sockets and many were different. I sized the holes for the largest standard sockets (not impact sockets)

Hello all,

This is something I cooked up quickly as I needed to convert all of my old Empire models into AoS round bases, for a tournament.

It changes the 20mm square base into a neat (approx 28mm) circular base. The bottom bit of this converter is flexible enough to fit over the existing base and is bevelled to match the original pretty closely, for a seamless (enough) look. It can later be removed easily for playing games that still require square "regimental" order like KoW etc

Thank you,
Alex

PS. Got the idea from seeing Joseanes's version of these, but wanted to include the bevel for a tighter look. Mine have a larger diameter though (to eliminate as much of the corners as I could). If you want a smaller version, check his out.

title: Nerf Vulcan EBF25 Li-on Battery Modification

description.text:
The Nerf Vulcan requires 6 D type batteries to operate. Since these are hard to come by and are quite expensive (even more so if rechargable) I came up with a mod to use 3 18650 type Li-On rechargable batteries that can be picked up on Ebay pretty cheaply. They might run out of juice a little sooner than the D cells, but are fast to charge.  
I designed this mod especially so that it doesn't require any modification of the original battery compartment. The 3 Li-On cells provide a little higher voltage/more power than the 6 D cells (11 vs 9V) but IMHO not so much more that it should damage the motor. However, use this at your own risk (I take no responsibility).

To make this easy printable, I chose to not use supports but glue the different parts together with acetone. However, I have included full designs for those that want to try to print it in one go.  
Also, it is necessary to make an electrical connection using soldering iron. For the bottom I used a round-cut part of a tin can and the top is a nail, both connected by a wire. This is visible on the photos.  
The supports are not necessary, but provide extra support so the whole contraption stays in place.

description.text:
NSFW "Thing"

When building a household helper robot, this would be the most important part - his "thing". Intentionally designed to be machine-like, sorta art deco, and to be a young robot's parts.

Make sure you seal it with Z-poxy, conformal silicone (food grade like Smooth-Sil), ABS slurry, and/ or use a condom over it to reduce the chances of harboring bacteria in your porous print if this is used for anything more than intimidation sitting on a shelf or use as a coat hook.

Might be nice in ninjaflex or TPU vs hard PLA or ABS.

Scale it to whatever size you are (un-?) comfortable with or to fall within the build shortcomings of your printer. It's "normal" sized at 1:1. PM me if there are proportions you'd like to change and I'll think about it.

The "base" is designed to also allow attachment to fixed objects (like a robot, wall, etc) or to a belt (figure out why you and a friend would want that - use acorn nuts or smooth rivets, inspecting for sharp edges) and to be easily held in slippery situations.

Tilt the model so the needed supports are on the base, otherwise you'll have some sanding to do on the model to get rid of support zits. It should print without supports if you tilt it properly in your slicer.

Novelty item - use at your own risk. Don't put it anywhere you can't explain to unexpected people.

Ahem...enjoy

description.text:

Mp Select mini V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I printed it on my Mp Select mini V2 in PLA with these settings.

Layer height (mm) : 0.15
Shell thickness (mm) : 1.2

Bottom/Top thickness (mm) : 1.2
Fill Density (%) : 10% (But I would recommend 30% for the top, 10% was barely enough to hold the top shell at the bottom of the Y on the Top part)

Print speed (mm/s) : 50
Printing temperature (C) : 195
Bed temperature (C) : 60

Support type : None for the Top, Touching buildplate for the bottom

Retraction speed (mm/s) : 40.0
Retraction distance (mm) 4.5

title: Thorens TP60 Turntable Headshell Clone with Finger Arm

description.text: Tired of the high price people are charging for old Thorens Headshells so I built my own. Works great with my Thorens TD-165 for a spare cartridge. Will follow with video and details when I have more time. I have to thank Jacques who gave me this idea and who designed a very good useable working model himself. In order to save time I used his mounting bullet and side panels to save on design time. The rest was done by meticulously tracing out an original headshell from various angles and doing my best to stitch it together and get it as accurate as possible. Of course I had to stray a slight bit from some original dimensions because of material differences and limitations of my capability as I am still quite new at 3D modeling. Improvement suggestions are welcomed. More details on the electrical side to follow when I have time (otherwise PM me if possible in this web site)

title: Anet A8 Prusa Top Frame Brace (M10 variant)

description.text:
I had a 3/8" threaded rod from the hardware store, so I needed to adjust this a little.

While I was in there, I realized that the design might be better as a wedge-shape to make sure it's nice and snug. I printed this in TPU to get a "rubber stopper" effect, but it should work just fine in PLA or whatever you typically use as well.

Print 2, put 2 bolts (3/8" bolts for 3/8" rod, naturally) on each end of the rod to lock them down. I'd probably cut the rod needed down to 320mm or less instead of the 350 recommended on the original as well since this part is smaller.

I've included my OpenSCAD file as well so you can customize the spacing or whatever you'd need to.

comments.text: Thanks for uploading your remix, the wedge shape is a good idea, wish I'd thought of it.
comments.author: FredGenius

comments.text: Really good actually, I tend to print at higher speeds (because I'm impatient haha) and I noticed a big increase in stability with this mod.

description.text:
This sleeve is perfect to insert some PTFE bushings like the ones sold on AliExpress:

https://www.aliexpress.com/item/JETTING-10PCS-Wear-Resisting-SF-1-Self-Lubricating-Bearing-Bushing-8x10x12mm/32825258959.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.t7Istv

The new PTFE bushings with this sleeve gives the X carriage new rigidity and no more Z axis wobble.

Just push out the existing bearings and insert the new sleeve.
Put a bit of loctite on the bearings to keep them in place.

description.text: divertitevi

print_settings.Notes:: Simplify 3D's gap fill did a great job with the thin walls, 3 upper and lower layers and 2 shells.  It printed the outer and inner shell and it's gap fill make a thicker bead in the middle for a solid wall.  Other software or printers may need to play with tweaking the settings some so that you get a single solid wall instead of 2 detached shells.

description.text:
This sign is intended to be lit up to warn others not to disturb you when you're recording. (We chose "On Air" as it's a lot less letters than "Recording" and has a similar meaning.)

We haven't figured out the electronics yet. Planning to use something like a WS2812b LED with a wifi microcontroller. "Hey Cortana, I'm recording now!" (or something like that).

There are 2 and 3 sided wall-mountable versions and a 2 sided desk mount version. Each has variants with and without integral letters, so you can either print letters in another color or paint them. The 3 sided version also comes in a 2-part one with a removable top to avoid the support marks showing through the translucent filament.

Included is a wall mount intended for the wall signs to hang from.

Full disclosure: Gearbest gave me the CR-10 that I printed this with, so I feel sort of obligated to put it through it's paces.

If you like my things, I don't mind Tips, but checking out our Lego R2-D2 YouTube page also helps!

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

None

Notes:

Obviously print the sign in translucent filament. We used ABS. You can scale the whole thing up or down some if desired.

Printing the letters in something like black and gluing them on later is probably better than painting, but there's a 1-piece version if you want to paint it.

The 3 sided version also comes in a two-part varient. That's good because then you can print the parts and avoid the lines left by the supports.

No support is needed, except for the single section 3 sided version. I used 5% for that.

The letters probably don't need infill either, but I'd use 10% or so for the wall mount.

Simplify 3D's gap fill did a great job with the thin walls, 3 upper and lower layers and 2 shells. It printed the outer and inner shell and it's gap fill make a thicker bead in the middle for a solid wall. Other software or printers may need to play with tweaking the settings some so that you get a single solid wall instead of 2 detached shells.

Painting Letters

If you choose to print the one-piece version with the painted letters, then you'll probably need to make sure to use paint. Markers don't work on filament because they wick into the gaps and a terrible smudge oozes out from the letters.

I knew that and still tried a marker with horrid results. (fortunately some alcohol cleaned it off).

Gluing Letters

Be careful with the letter orientation. In particular, the "O" isn't symmetrical. So make sure they look right before gluing.

Obviously the glue/solvent depends on the material you print with. We printed in ABS, so used MEK (not recommended because it's nasty).

Note that the solvent makes it easy to smear the black letters onto the translucent sign, so be careful not to smudge them.

Gluing the Two-Part Top

If you print the two-part 3 sided sign, use care gluing the top on. Any solvent that glues the parts together is also likely to smudge or streak the clear parts if it drips down the sides.

We had luck putting a thin layer of solvent along the top edge and then pressing the top onto that. A bit didn't get sealed though, so we had to try some more and caused a dreaded drip.

Wall Mount

One part is a wall (or desk?) mount to secure the sign. It's intended to be affixed to the wall with two screws, and then the sign hangs from that. Since it depends a bit on gravity, it probably won't be great on a desk (I'm working on that.)

I used Sketchup

The file's included. I build the base for the sign, then stamped out some letters. The biggest trick was making the recessed hole for the letters. It has to be a little bigger than the letters, so that was a bit of painful hand-editing to make the recessed bits 0.5mm bigger on all sides.

In the future I think I'll try the Fredo6 Round Corner extension. I think that by "embossing" the letters on the flat surface, then I can "round" the corners of that surface (like with only 1 side to round it), and then chop off the rest of it. Then extrude the resulting letter, which should be slightly bigger than the original.

comments.author: fxdurieux

comments.text:
Hi
I have a Creality CR10 and two heavily modified CTC replicator clones. Most parts are 0.2 layer height with varying infill depending on the part.
I don't obsess with getting a perfect finish off the printer as I know I will be sanding and painting the parts.
I use Simplify 3D which really supercharged the CTC printers and is great for saving plastic on larger prints as you can adjust the infill. I cannot recommend it enough if you print a lot.
Hope this helps.
comments.author: fxdurieux

comments.text: Thanks for you answer. About sanding, if your using PLA, what grain do you use for sandpaper ? And do you hand sand or machine sand ? PLA don't melt ? And continue your wondelfull job, it's a pleasure for the eyes ...
comments.author: 300zxcolin

comments.text:
Hi
It depends on the size of the part. Large parts I will use 180 grit moving to 240 grit. This is good enough to then use primer filler which is then wet sanded with 400grit.
I use a variety of sanding sticks and blocks and also nail emery boards are useful for small items or you can cut them to shapes to get into difficult areas.
Recently I have tried using a spray primer filler but brushed on by hand onto the raw print and sanding this down. This is getting better but I am still experimenting.
You are correct that PLA will melt if you get it hot and sanding creates heat so either be careful or wet sand. And remember to allow your parts to thoroughly dry after wet sanding as the print is very porous and will absorb water like a sponge.
comments.author: fxdurieux

comments.text: Last question : what do you think about dichloromethane vapor trick to smooth surface (l'île aceton for ABS) ? Thanks again
comments.author: 300zxcolin

comments.text:
Never tried it.
Let me know if you have any success
comments.author: fxdurieux

comments.text:
Acetone does not work on any PLA I have eve used. I think there is another chemical that might work but I can't remember the name.
When I tried it the parts just went milky white and soft.
Chemical smoothing is really messy and time consuming and it will tend to round off all the crisp edges. Fine for sculptures and things like that but not much use for parts that fit together or have to be painted afterwards. All that before you start to consider the health risks of heating chemicals in your house..........
In my experience there is no shortcut to getting a good finish. Its like painting a car, the more time you spend on surface preparation the better the end result. If your printer is set up well it should minimise the amount of sanding you need to do.
I'm going to do some experiments with epoxy resin soon. I'll let you know how I get on.

I use this setup for a beer fermentation controller, for this reason, the current version only has an opening for the micro USB connector and another opening for the 1-Wire Cable, I don't need the other connectors. title: Anet A8 - Original X Axis Mounts V2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an almost exact replica of the stock Anet A8 X Axis mounts in the newer molded versions.

The reason I created these are because I wanted to change the color sheme of the printer from black-white to black-orange, because it just looks awesome and the stock mounts had some problematic tolerances in the holes for the axles. Therfore their distance was on the right side about 0.2mm larger than on the left side which caused a carefully adjusted sleigh to have a large resistance on one of the sides.

When you want to print the mounts, please take notice of the Print section of this model.

If you like it, you may also check out my other Anet A8 and 3d printing things:

  • Customizeable Cooling Fan Blades
  • Filament Guides for the Anet A8 in 6 variations (0°, 45°, 90°) Vertical and Horizontal
  • Linear Bushing / Bearing - LM8UU - IGUS like - with mount
  • Spoolhoder tube to lower rotational resistance (requires two axle bearings)
  • Cable Clip (Anet like)
  • Improved Customizeable Anet A8 E3Dv6 Mount with 40mm Fan Mount

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50% or more

Notes:

Since these parts carry the complete x-Axis, even the smallest tolerance can have negative effects on the resulting prints and might decrease your print quality compared to the stock parts. Therefore your printer should be calibrated very precisly with tolerances of less than 0.1mm in all 3 directions.

Furthermore the models are created to match the stock dimensions precisely without any print tolerances taken into account. You have to compensate your individual print tolerances by setting for example the horizontal expansion in Cura or similar parameter in other slicers. In addition you will need to post process the mounts to make them work. For this a 3mm drill, a 7.8mm drill and a vice are required. Instead of the vice you can try to use a rubber hammer (see the post printing section).

Since the mounts carry the complete x-axis and the tension of the x-axis belt, they should be printed very stable. PLA is sufficient, but you should use a large infill of 50% or more. The printing requires support structures, because the model is printed up side down to make the bearing holder and the vertical screw nut holes to be vertical since vertical holes usally turn out with the highest precision. For the supports I set the overhang threshold to 80° so that the only the largest hole for the x-motor is being supported

After the print the first step is to remove all the support structures.

Afterwards you should take a 3mm drill and drill up the holes for the x-motor, for the vertical screw nuts and the belt idler. Now you can already mount the idler with the same parts as in the original setup.

The next step is to disassemble the original mounts. You can already take the vertical screw nuts off and assemble them to the printed mounts. Be careful to tighthen the screw first whichs hole is the least affected by potential warping.

Next you have to disassemble the linear bearings. This workd very well using a vice and a part of similar diameter to push the berings out. Alternatively you can try using a rubber hammer. The assembling of the bearings works the same way. I found it easier to start pushing the bearings in from the downside and then using a vice to push them in the final position, cause the fit is very tight. If this does'nt work for you, take a hot air gun and heat the part up a little bit, so the plastic gets a softer.

The last step is to work out the axles holes. This is the most critical part, since you want the axles to fit tight and very precisely, but on the other hand being easy to push in and pull out. I took a 7.8mm drill which is 0.2mm below the nominal diameter of the axles to compensate for potential tolerances and drilled the holes up with it. This should go very easy since the holes are printed with a nominal diameter of 8mm and you only have to remove fragments from the bridging at the top of the holes. Afterwards carefulls remove all chippings from the holes and try to fit the axles in. Don't use too much stength oterwise you might not get them out again. If the fit is too tight, again take the 7.8mm drill and move it up and down through the holes to remove tiny amounts of material and then try again to fit the axles. Do this until the axles fit into the holes perfectly. If necessary take a 7.9mm or 8mm drill.

Afterwards you have to assemble the threads for the setscrews used to secure the axles on the right mount. They can be taken out of the original mount using a 3mm screw and tongs. To push them into the printed mount again use a vice or a rubber hammer.

Now you only have to reassemble and recalibrate your printer.

For making these models I first had to disassemble the original mounts completly to measure them using a caliper. Then I had to reassemble them using the original parts to be able to print the replicas and afterwards I had to disassemble everything again and reassamble with the new parts, which took me several hours overall.

I hope you find my work useful.

title: Socket and Stand for dji Phantom 3 Battery Parallel Charger Plate

description.text:
This is a charger socket made for the parallel battery charger for Dji Phantom 3 drone (the last 2 picture is the charger). This charger can be bought separately, and its a more convenient alternative because it can queue 3 battery charging at a time.

I made this for my father cause the original charging position is not really convenient (the last image is how the battery is charged) especially when you charge multiple battery, and more so when taking them out one by one.

So this is the socket and stand for the charging plate. It really made putting in and out batteries easier. The upper part fixed the charging plate so it doesn't move too much. I also made the body as tall as the batteries so it sits properly on flat surface.

Hope this helps!!

NOTE:

  1. Once you put in the plate in the socket, it's really hard to take out that I had to break the prototype.
  2. Before printing, rotate the object like the 2nd Image. The support will be easier to take out that way

Printer:

FlashForge Inventor

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Low is okay

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I suggest rotating the object like the 2nd Image in this model. That orientation eases the printer to make the support rather than having the back side on the bed.

I used 10% infill, but it's up to you. I tried the socket prototype with 5% infill to test the model and it weigh quite well too.

Resolution doesn't matter much cause this thing doesn't need detail. I put on low to get it done faster.

Hope it helps.

If you want to make charger plate socket for other model of Dji drones (like Mavic and Inspire that has this kind of charger), make sure to measure with the batteries intact.

I'm a novice in 3D modelling...

...so I used autoCAD for the lines (because AutoCAD is easy if you are working with numbers) and then I transfer to Sketchup to fill the object, just because I still couldn't do it all alone in Sketchup.

Let me start by thanking the people who inspired me to develop this violin remix. I especially want to thank firecardenal, on Thingiverse, who provided my initial inspiration and who by his numerous designs, showed the variety that could be achieved. I also wish to thank Stepan83, Jaxelsson on Thingiverse, and bchan on Pinshape who contributed parts used in this remix.

I liked the clean styling of the “Easy printing Electric Violin” and the classic look of the “Mina Violin (Electric),” but I wanted to see if I could make an even more traditional look while keeping with the modern style of other 3D printed electric violins. Most of my changes are purely cosmetic but are meant to pay tribute to the original work of such masters as Stradivarius.

Rev 2 corrected error in Lower Neck and Upper Bout for correct attachment.

Jan 9, 2018, Added: Violin Bridge (Electric), (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2576368) by EngAl as this bridge appears more properly fitted.

Jan 23, 2018, Added: File "body_waist_F_holes_through" where the "F" holes pass all the way through the waist and a file "eViolin Body Waist with F holes plus base" with the "F" holes that pass almost all the way through but the base covers the backside of the waist. This should correct the unsupported cavity in the original waist with "F" hole file. That file will be removed.

Infill:

20%

Notes:

All parts can be printed without supports, except for the chin-rest
Recommended printing parameters:
4 Shell thickness.
3 top down solid thickness.
20 % infill
0.20mm. layer heights.

If you print on ABS filament, you can use acetone or PVC pipe glue to bind the parties. If you print on PLA, then use a epoxi glue.
If you do not want to paint the PLA, be very careful not to sand or file any of the exposed areas, instead use a small Exacto knife to clean up edges.
If you choose to paint you can use a sanding paper and patching paste for automotive jobs to leave a smooth surface to paint on color of your choice. Don't forget to use a primer paint.

Materials List:
Printed parts – 10 pcs
Body Waist with F Holes 2 pcs
Chin Rest & Shoulder Supports 2 pcs
Neck Parts 3 pcs
Upper & Lower Bouts 2 pcs
Bridge 1 pc

Violin Pickup and Preamp - for under bridge (easy to find on eBay or Amazon)
Guitar Tuning Pegs - 4pcs (2 left/2 right)
violin strings – 4 pcs
Threaded Metal Rod M8 x 370mm – 1pcs
Screws:
m4x25 - 9pcs
m4x50 - 1pcs
m4x40 - 2pcs
m3x8 - 4pcs (for tuning pegs)
m2x10 - 4pcs (for electronic preamp)
Nuts:
M4 – 16 pcs
m3 long nut - 4pcs for hot installation in holes (for pegs screws) or you can use M3 Brass Wood Screw Inserts for the tuners - 4pcs (likely need to drill out a bit for a smooth fit, brass is soft and will break if it has much resistance in the plastic)

I felt the scroll work at the top of the neck and the “F” holes in the body are part of that classical look but which were missing. I found the scroll “SLA Violin – Scroll” part of the “Violin” by bchan (https://pinshape.com/items/24608-3d-printed-violin). I tried various necks but found the best fit using “elviolin_v2_neck_p1_wout_support” and “elviolin_v2_handle” for the upper bout from the “Elviolin v2” by Stepan83 (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:781491). Moving down the neck, I used “violin_neck_part2_better_pickup_wiring” for the lower fingerboard, “violin_neck_part3” for the tuning peg box, “body_lower_bout_basic2” fpr the lower bout and the “body_waist_block” from the “Mina Violin (Electric)” by Jaxelsson (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2122773) I then cut “F” holes into the body waist. Since I wanted to use the chin rest, “EZ2PRINT03” from the “Easy printing Electric Violin” by firecardenal (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:767536) I cut the chin rest support pegs from the lower bout of “EZ2PRINT02” part of the “Easy printing Electric Violin” and added them to the lower bout from the Mina Violin. I wanted to accessorize as completely as possible so I included the “SHOULDER_SUPPORT” from “Captain Nemo Electric Violin” by firecardenal (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1642508) and the “BRIDGE” from “Rock Star Electric Violin V-3”, also by firecardenal (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:982555).

comments.text: Why did you make the F holes hollow under them instead of all the way through to the base? From a printing clean up this will be almost impossible to remove without breaking would be better to go all the way down inside. I tried editing the brep but it would be easier to redraw the holes from scratch then try to extrude them solid.
comments.author: Crixe

comments.text: I did start with the F holes all the way through, then filled in only the base. Perhaps that would have been better, but I wanted to try to make them more like the traditional. If you're interested,I can include the original F holes all the way through and with just the base filled.
comments.author: Crixe

comments.text: Yes please, I love it with the F holes but without dissolvable supports I'd never be able to print it as is and clean out the support.
comments.author: JAMott

comments.text: I've replaced the original waist with "F" holes with two options. the first has the "F" holes going all the way through the waist pieces therefore having the holes on both sides of each waist piece. The second option has the "F" holes going through the waist but with a fairly thin layer of the base left to keep the holes closed on the back. I don't know why I didn't realize that the cavity would not print properly without impossible to remove supports. I guess my only excuse is the this was my first project. Hope you enjoy the new options.
comments.author: Crixe

comments.text: It's okay I do design for a 3d print company for a living that's the only reason I notice these things. Even after 2 years of doing nothing but 3d printable designs I still make mistakes. Looks great will print very nicely with the fully through holes too. I'll post pictures when I finish the violin. I won't be using the scrolled top because I like the more minimalistic version on the original (and I have a violin with one already). Also on the scroll it has a cavity in it that I'd recommend filling in for easier print would allow for more consistent fusion between the two though working with STL's can be a pain if you don't have the source files fusion 360 can do a conversion into a Brep but you'll still have some line cleanup on the flat faces to edit it correctly.
comments.author: JAMott

comments.text: Thanks for the feedback. I was trying to clean up the scroll but found the surfaces were curved and I was having a difficult time getting them to smooth out like I wanted them. I also wanted to fill the cavity but again, had to deal with the curves for which I was not happy with the results. I'm using TinkerCAD and I am still just starting out. Perhaps I'll learn how to deal with the curves and will then update my model. Meanwhile, the neck top came directly from the ElViolin V2 (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:781491) by stepan83 if you prefer to have a neck without the scroll.

title: Traxxas Street Sport Modified Body Mounts

description.text:
I bought a Vaterra body for my Ascender. I then realized it was for the Vaterra V-100S (a 4wd sports car). So I decided to use it on my Traxxas Street Sport! The problem? The body already had holes drilled in it and I didn't want to un-pretty the body by drilling a "hole" bunch more. (Heh, get it? Hole bunch? Instead of whole bunch? OK, I'll stop.)

Um. Yeah, so there's a left-front and a right-front body mount, and two identical rears. The fronts offset the body pins by a bit to bring them farther apart and rear-ward by a tad. The rears are moved back about an inch. This is based on measurements of the original design by Traxxas.

Printer Brand:

PowerSpec

Printer:

PowerSpec 3D Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Any. I'd suggest 0.1 or 0.2mm.

Infill:

100%

Notes:

You may have to re-drill some of the holes. Also, Traxxas recommended, in the Street Sport's manual, cutting the front body posts to size after you are happy with the body fitment. I left them long and they fit the truck body nicely.

This prints on its own sort of raft. I accounted for the thickness of the raft when designing it, so all you have to do is trim out the body posts with scissors, remove the filler material, and reprocess your body pin holes and pin sizes if necessary.
I designed this by taking measurements of the Street Sport's original body posts and modifying them in Blender.

title: Street Sport Front Bearing Sedan Wheel Hub

description.text:
I wanted to use standard sedan wheels on my Traxxas Street Sport, but it has a goofy bushing design for the front wheels. I designed these hollowed-out wheel hubs so I could use standard R/C ball bearings (5x11x4mm) in the front wheels. You may need to file out the small hole at the bottom to fit your axle if your print shrinks after cooling.

The bearings I use are Traxxas part number 5116. They are 5 x 11 x 4mm. You may need to adjust your z dimension to account for part cooling and wheel thickness to get the wheel-to-nut interface perfect.

title: A5 GoPro Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update: A5 GoPro Mount v1.1 now is adjustable up to 50mm with holes every 10mm.

This is a GoPro style mount for the JGAurora A5 3D Printer. It can be used with other GoPro style connectors or parts from my other designs:
Pi Zero + Camera GoPro Adapter: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2546114
PiCam Mount for A3 - GoPro Style: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2679030

Printer:

JGAurora A5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10-30%

Notes:

Print as oriented and you won't need any supports and it will fit (diagonally) on the print bed.
I sliced this with Simplify3D using variable infill densities: 10% for the main rod and 30% for the arms. I also printed it with a 1.6mm shell for maximum strength. PETG is strongly recommended.

Installation...

You're going to have to partially remove the print bed to install this. The side arms slide into the print bed carriage frame and are held in place with the bed level screws.

description.text:
Squirrel feeder.

I made this for a little red squirrel that lives in my garden. Now I can watch and enjoy when it sits at this 3D printed squirrel feeder. It didn't take long for it to figure out how the lid worked.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm or less

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I used 3 perimeters, but less will do.

Use a 2mm drill-bit to drill the holes clean.
Use 1.75mm filament as hinge. Make sure the lid move very easily. File/sand if it doesn't.
Melt the ends of the filament with a soldering iron.

Fit some transparent sheet in the front. There should be some ventilation at the lid top and at the platform.

Securely fasten the squirrel feeder. Take care it's a place that doesn't attract mice & rats.

Watch and enjoy!
