Remade Prusa i3 E3D V5 Hotend/ Fan Mount for J-Head

A map maker for Revomaze puzzles. With this mapper, I was able to solve the Indigo maze in 8 hours.

I used 2 M4 socket head cap screws, 2 washers, and 2 nylon lock nuts for assembly.

Updates:

  • 2017 Dec 30 - Fixed an error in the instructions regarding orientation. See step 6 for the change.

Assembly:

  1. Print the test piece and check the fit of your pen in the hole before printing the larger pieces. Make any necessary changes to the model and print all the the pieces.

  2. Insert one bolt, washer, and lock nut in the handle and leave the screw loose. Do the same for the map holder.

  3. Place the handle on the side of the puzzle with the dot marker, aligning the gap in the handle with the serial number on the puzzle's core. Tighten the bolt with enough pressure to keep the handle in place, but not so tight that it breaks the plastic. This is a 3D printed part after all.

  4. Cut a strip of paper 2 1/2" wide and place it on the map holder.

  5. Slide the Map holder on the end of the Revomaze opposite the handle.

  6. Rotate the handle until the space opposite the gap lines up with the dot on the puzzle. Hold the handle and puzzle still while rotating the map holder until the gap in the map holder lines up with the arm on the handle. Tighten the bolt, again being careful not to over tighten and damage the printed part. This alignment will indicate when the puzzle is in the solved position.

  7. Place a piece of tape over the gap between the ends of the paper and trim the end. Make sure your pen will write on the tape you choose.

  8. Cut a rubber band and tie loops in the ends. Place the pen holder on a ball point pen, and place the elastic loops on the hooks of the pen holder.

  9. Hook the elastic under the arm of the handle and insert the pen.

  10. Solve the puzzle!

author: evox

title: Gears and wheels for 130 dc motor

description.text:
This gear and wheel set is designed to fit with a 130 size, 3v dc motor. It runs fast due to the low gear ratio (1 : 21.1). I plan to use 2 sets for a wheeled robot.

A set contains support, gear8 for the motor, and 2 copies of gear8-41 and wheel.

The holes on the support are to be tapped for M3 screws as the axles. The intermediate gear is held on place by the wheel, which is held in place by the screw head. I use 24mm i.d. x 2.5mm o-ring for the tires.

This is a planetary gearbox for use with 130 size, 3v dc motor. The gear ratio is 1 : 15.5. Print 3 copies of the gear9 as the planet gears.

The 5 holes in the support are to be tapped for 3mm screw. 4 screws secure the annulus part, and the central screw (30mm length) become the axle for the sun gear and the wheel.

The central holes in the gears and the wheel are 3.2mm diameter by design, they should allow an 3mm screw freely rotating inside but I still need to drill clean the holes with 3mm bit due to z axis wobble on my printer. The 3 other holes on the wheel are to be tapped for 3mm screws (10mm length) too, for the planets' axles.

I used a rubber band cut from a bicycle inner tube as the tire. I made this design for a mini sumo robot (10cm x 10cm limit). Maybe the gear ratio is too low but I will give it a try.

Use wheel2 for use with 36mm i.d. x 3mm o-ring tire.

comments.text: Rough on gears, motor gear likes to slide off, but a fun build

description.text: motherboard cover

print_settings.Notes:: I printed the prototype with PETG filament.

description.text:
Work In Progress

Purpose

This design aims to create a cheap, robust and modular camera slider that can be easily extended in length.

Bill of materials

  • 2020 extrusion profile
  • Stepper motor w/ GT2 pulley
  • ATmega MCU (e.g. ATmega 328P used in arduino pro mini)
  • Stepper motor driver (e.g. A4988)
  • GT2 belt

To do

  1. Create extrusion sliders
  2. Create camera plate
  3. Create intermediate holding point for tripod attachment
  4. Add parameters to allow custom design (2040 profiles, larger camera plate, etc)

Change log

27/12/2017

  • Initial design

04/01/2018

  • Add extrusion wheel
  • Removed customizer

Printer:

Anet Evolution

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The "1/4 - 20" screw hole for camera mount has not the thread. You can easily use your screw to make the thread, paying attention to push down while turning the screw.

All other screw used in the design are referred to the metric standard (M3 for motor support and M5 for 2020 type-I extrusion), in particular the holes are slightly larger to ease the screwing.

I printed the prototype with PETG filament.
